title: FL Lady Bug
text:
FL Lady Bug (1945–1974) was a <a href="Quarter%20Horse">Quarter Horse</a> mare who was never raced or was shown in a <a href="horse%20show">horse show</a>, yet was made famous for her speedy offspring.
Life.
FL Lady Bug was registered as number 9733 in the <a href="American%20Quarter%20Horse%20Association">American Quarter Horse Association</a>'s (or AQHA) stud book. A <a href="Sorrel%20%28horse%29">sorrel</a> <a href="mare">mare</a>, she was foaled in 1945 and bred by W. A. Yeager of <a href="Woodward%2C%20Oklahoma">Woodward, Oklahoma</a>. Her owners at the time she was registered were Bill and Alive Likins of <a href="Davis%2C%20Oklahoma">Davis, Oklahoma</a>. Her sire, Sergeant, was bred to a daughter of his full brother, Will Stead, to produce Lady Bug. Thus, FL Lady Bug was inbred to both Billy McCue and Silver. Her second dam was an unnamed quarter mare from the <a href="J%20A%20Ranch">J A Ranch</a> in Texas.
Breeding record.
FL Lady Bug had fourteen <a href="foal">foal</a>s, eleven of whom started races. Ten of those starters were winners, with one Champion Quarter Running Two Year Old Filly – Top Ladybug, three <a href="Stakes%20race">stakes</a> winners, and ten Race Register of Merit winners. All ten of her Register of Merit qualifiers were sired by different <a href="stallions">stallions</a>.
Death and honors.
She died on March 1, 1974.
FL Lady Bug was inducted into the <a href="American%20Quarter%20Horse%20Hall%20of%20Fame">AQHA Hall of Fame</a> in 1999.
